comment.author: 11572312@N00
comment._content: Her husband was a British diplomat and winner of the Nobel Peace prize. Their son Neville Chamberlain would become a famous (or infamous) British Prime Minister. Austin: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austen_Chamberlain Neville: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neville_Chamberlain

comment.author: 61849735@N00
comment._content:
What a beautiful dress.
This was the second wife probably and her name was Harriet.  She was a cousin to the first who who died in childbirth.  This wife also died in childbirth.  

My goodness how sad..

comment.author: 24509127@N06
comment._content: The date on the side of the photograph reads 1-24-13.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Good observation dyzzilet!  What we have is a photograph taken 1-24-13 of an earlier photograph.  We'll need more information about the original image before we fix the source data.

comment.author: 27600151@N04
comment._content:
Harry Angstrom is incorrect.  Austen and Neville Chamberlain were the sons (half-brothers) of Joseph Chamberlain a prominent politician in Victorian England.  Austen won the Nobel Prize and Neville was the Prime Minister associated with the Munich agreement.

Joseph Chamberlain (no relation)

comment.author: 27600151@N04
comment._content:
Further thoughts.

According to Wikipedia, Austen Chamberlain died in 1937 at the age of 73.  He would therefore be 49 at the time this photograph was taken if the date given is correct (1913) - not too old to be the father of the young girl, but gives pause for thought.

The date is in the American style, rather than the English style (which would be 24-1-13) so either it is not a date or one could surmise it has been added by an American curator or it is a purely American photograph.

Tentative conclusion:  This Mrs Austen Chamberlain is not the wife of the British politician.

Joseph Chamberlain (still no relation)
